exercises.question: By this time next year, I ___ my master's degree in engineering.
exercises.answer: will have finished
exercises.hint: Action completed before a future point.
exercises.example_sentence: By this time next year, I will have finished my master's degree in engineering.

exercises.question: Which sentence describes an action in progress at a specific future time?
options: This time tomorrow, I will be flying to New York.
This time tomorrow, I will fly to New York.
This time tomorrow, I will have flown to New York.
exercises.answer: This time tomorrow, I will be flying to New York.
exercises.example_sentence: This time tomorrow, I will be flying to New York for a business conference.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use the causative 'get'.
exercises.answer: I finally got my brother to help me move
exercises.example_sentence: I finally got my brother to help me move into my new apartment.

exercises.question: Match the causative verbs with their grammatical patterns.
exercises.example_sentence: My parents let me stay out late on weekends.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'We will have been living here for ten years by the end of the month.'
exercises.answer: We will have been living here for ten years by the end of the month.
exercises.example_sentence: We will have been living here for ten years by the end of the month.

exercises.question: My boss made me ___ the entire report because of a few small errors.
exercises.answer: rewrite
exercises.example_sentence: My boss made me rewrite the entire report because of a few small errors.

exercises.question: Which form suggests a scheduled future event?
options: The train leaves at 9:00 PM tonight.
The train will leave at 9:00 PM tonight.
The train is leaving at 9:00 PM tonight.
exercises.answer: The train leaves at 9:00 PM tonight.
exercises.example_sentence: The train leaves at 9:00 PM tonight, so don't be late.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a future perfect sentence.
exercises.answer: They won't have finished the work by Friday
exercises.example_sentence: They won't have finished the work by Friday, given the current progress.

exercises.question: Match the future time markers with the appropriate tense.
exercises.example_sentence: By next week, I will have submitted my application.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Will you be using your car this evening, or can I borrow it?'
exercises.answer: Will you be using your car this evening, or can I borrow it?
exercises.example_sentence: Will you be using your car this evening, or can I borrow it for a few hours?

exercises.question: Please don't call me between 2 and 4; I ___ a meeting then.
exercises.answer: will be having
exercises.example_sentence: Please don't call me between 2 and 4; I will be having a meeting then.

exercises.question: Which causative indicates 'persuasion'?
options: I got him to check the data.
I had him check the data.
I made him check the data.
exercises.answer: I got him to check the data.
exercises.example_sentence: I finally got him to check the data after explaining its importance.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a polite future question.
exercises.answer: Will you be joining us for dinner tonight
exercises.example_sentence: Will you be joining us for dinner tonight at the new Italian restaurant?

exercises.question: Match the situation to the causative verb.
exercises.example_sentence: The strict teacher makes her students study for an hour every day.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I had the mechanic look at the engine because of the noise.'
exercises.answer: I had the mechanic look at the engine because of the noise.
exercises.example_sentence: I had the mechanic look at the engine because of the strange noise it was making.

exercises.question: Don't worry, the film ___ by the time you get home.
exercises.answer: won't have started
exercises.example_sentence: Don't worry, the film won't have started by the time you get home.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct for 'permission'?
options: My boss let me leave early today.
My boss let me to leave early today.
My boss lets me leaving early today.
exercises.answer: My boss let me leave early today.
exercises.example_sentence: My boss let me leave early today since I had finished all my tasks.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use the Future Perfect Continuous.
exercises.answer: She will have been working here for five years
exercises.hint: Ongoing action up to a future point.
exercises.example_sentence: Next month, she will have been working here for five years.

exercises.question: I'll ___ the assistant send you the documents right away.
exercises.answer: have
exercises.example_sentence: I'll have the assistant send you the documents right away.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They'll have finished the construction by the end of 2027.'
exercises.answer: They'll have finished the construction by the end of 2027.
exercises.example_sentence: They'll have finished the construction by the end of 2027.

exercises.question: The company developed a new system ___ employees can track their progress in real-time.
exercises.answer: whereby
exercises.example_sentence: The company developed a new system whereby employees can track their progress in real-time.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence using a formal prepositional relative clause.
options: The candidate with whom I spoke was very impressive.
The candidate who I spoke with him was very impressive.
The candidate whose I spoke to was very impressive.
exercises.answer: The candidate with whom I spoke was very impressive.
exercises.example_sentence: The candidate with whom I spoke during the interview was very impressive.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with a noun clause as a subject.
exercises.answer: What surprised me most was his total honesty
exercises.hint: The 'What' clause acts as the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: What surprised me most was his total honesty about the mistake.

exercises.question: Match the relative pronouns with their specific functions.
exercises.hint: Think about the relationship between clauses.
exercises.example_sentence: He arrived late, which annoyed everyone in the office.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The woman whose car was stolen has already contacted the police.'
exercises.answer: The woman whose car was stolen has already contacted the police.
exercises.example_sentence: The woman whose car was stolen has already contacted the police.

exercises.question: The reason ___ I am calling is to confirm our appointment for tomorrow.
exercises.answer: why
exercises.example_sentence: The reason why I am calling is to confirm our appointment for tomorrow morning.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'which' to refer to a previous idea?
options: She passed all her exams, which was a huge relief.
She passed all her exams, that was a huge relief.
She passed all her exams, what was a huge relief.
exercises.answer: She passed all her exams, which was a huge relief.
exercises.example_sentence: She passed all her exams with honors, which was a huge relief to her parents.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence with 'in which'.
exercises.answer: The hotel in which we stayed was very old
exercises.hint: More formal than 'The hotel we stayed in'.
exercises.example_sentence: The hotel in which we stayed was very old but charming.

exercises.question: Match the noun clause beginnings with the logical ends.
exercises.example_sentence: Whether he comes to the party or not depends on his work schedule.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I don't know what you are talking about, but it sounds interesting.'
exercises.answer: I don't know what you are talking about, but it sounds interesting.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't know what you are talking about, but it sounds interesting.

exercises.question: The project, ___ was completed ahead of schedule, was a great success.
exercises.answer: which
exercises.example_sentence: The project, which was completed ahead of schedule, was a great success.

exercises.question: Choose the most formal option: 'The house...'
options: The house in which I grew up has been demolished.
The house where I grew up in has been demolished.
The house which I grew up has been demolished.
exercises.answer: The house in which I grew up has been demolished.
exercises.example_sentence: The house in which I grew up has unfortunately been demolished.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence with 'whose'.
exercises.answer: The author whose book is a best-seller is here
exercises.example_sentence: The author whose book is a best-seller is here for the signing.

exercises.question: Match the relative structures with their level of formality.

pairs.left: The man to whom I spoke

answer.left: The man to whom I spoke

exercises.example_sentence: The man to whom I spoke was extremely helpful.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Whoever made this mess needs to clean it up immediately.'
exercises.answer: Whoever made this mess needs to clean it up immediately.
exercises.example_sentence: Whoever made this mess needs to clean it up immediately.

exercises.question: They are looking for a candidate ___ primary language is Spanish.
exercises.answer: whose
exercises.example_sentence: They are looking for a candidate whose primary language is Spanish.

exercises.question: Choose the correct noun clause: 'I am not sure...'
options: I am not sure how much it costs.
I am not sure how much does it cost.
I am not sure how much it costed.
exercises.answer: I am not sure how much it costs.
exercises.example_sentence: I am not sure how much it costs, so I'll check the price tag.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'by which'.
exercises.answer: This is the process by which steel is made
exercises.example_sentence: This is the process by which steel is made in this factory.

exercises.question: ___ you do, don't forget to lock the door when you leave.
exercises.answer: Whatever
exercises.example_sentence: Whatever you do, don't forget to lock the door when you leave.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The town in which I was born has changed beyond recognition.'
exercises.answer: The town in which I was born has changed beyond recognition.
exercises.example_sentence: The town in which I was born has changed beyond recognition.

exercises.question: The ___ you practice speaking, the more confident you will become.
exercises.answer: more
exercises.example_sentence: The more you practice speaking, the more confident you will become.

exercises.question: Choose the most emphatic sentence: 'I just want a cup of coffee.'
options: All I want is a cup of coffee.
It is a cup of coffee I want.
A cup of coffee is what I want.
exercises.answer: All I want is a cup of coffee.
exercises.example_sentence: All I want is a cup of coffee and a few minutes of peace.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a 'What' cleft sentence.
exercises.answer: What we need is a good holiday
exercises.example_sentence: What we need is a good holiday to recharge our batteries.

exercises.question: Match the comparative structures with their meanings.
exercises.example_sentence: This laptop is by far the most expensive one in the store.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'It was the manager herself who authorized the refund.'
exercises.answer: It was the manager herself who authorized the refund.
exercises.example_sentence: It was the manager herself who authorized the refund.

exercises.question: The movie was ___ as exciting as the book I read last summer.
exercises.answer: nowhere near
exercises.example_sentence: The movie was nowhere near as exciting as the book I read last summer.

exercises.question: Choose the correct cleft sentence to emphasize the time: 'We met on Friday.'
options: It was on Friday that we met.
It was Friday when we met.
What was Friday was when we met.
exercises.answer: It was on Friday that we met.
exercises.example_sentence: It was on Friday that we met to discuss the new project.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a double comparative.
exercises.answer: The colder it gets the higher the heating bill is
exercises.example_sentence: The colder it gets, the higher the heating bill is during winter.

exercises.question: Match the emphasis structure to the part emphasized.

pairs.left: The thing that bothers me is...

answer.left: The thing that bothers me is...

exercises.example_sentence: The thing that bothers me is the lack of communication.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The harder you work, the luckier you get.'
exercises.answer: The harder you work, the luckier you get.
exercises.example_sentence: As the saying goes, the harder you work, the luckier you get.

exercises.question: This is ___ the best performance the actor has ever given.
exercises.answer: easily
exercises.example_sentence: This is easily the best performance the actor has ever given.

exercises.question: Identify the 'Pseudo-cleft' sentence.
options: What she needs is a long break.
She really needs a long break.
It is a break that she needs.
exercises.answer: What she needs is a long break.
exercises.example_sentence: What she needs is a long break after finishing the semester.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to emphasize an action.
exercises.answer: What he did was slam the door and leave
exercises.example_sentence: What he did was slam the door and leave the meeting in a hurry.

exercises.question: Match the modifiers with the adjectives.
exercises.example_sentence: His behavior during the presentation was totally unacceptable.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The more information we have, the better our decision will be.'
exercises.answer: The more information we have, the better our decision will be.
exercises.example_sentence: The more information we have, the better our decision will be.

exercises.question: I'm not ___ as talented as my sister when it comes to painting.
exercises.answer: half
exercises.example_sentence: I'm not half as talented as my sister when it comes to painting.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence to emphasize 'the money'.
options: It's the money that I'm worried about, not the time.
The money is what I'm worried about, not the time.
What I'm worried about is the money, not the time.
exercises.answer: It's the money that I'm worried about, not the time.
exercises.hint: Focus on the specific object using 'It'.
exercises.example_sentence: It's the money that I'm worried about, not the time it will take.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about continuous change.
exercises.answer: English is becoming easier and easier for her
exercises.example_sentence: English is becoming easier and easier for her to understand every day.

exercises.question: The ___ you wait, the more difficult it will be to find a seat.
exercises.answer: longer
exercises.example_sentence: The longer you wait, the more difficult it will be to find a seat.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'All they ever do is complain about the weather.'
exercises.answer: All they ever do is complain about the weather.
exercises.example_sentence: All they ever do is complain about the weather instead of enjoying the day.

exercises.question: Never ___ such a beautiful sunset in my entire life.
exercises.answer: have I seen
exercises.hint: Negative adverbial at the start requires question order.
exercises.example_sentence: Never have I seen such a beautiful sunset in my entire life.

exercises.question: Choose the correct perfect gerund: 'He was proud of...'
options: He was proud of having finished the marathon.
He was proud of to have finished the marathon.
He was proud of finish the marathon.
exercises.answer: He was proud of having finished the marathon.
exercises.example_sentence: He was proud of having finished the marathon despite his injury.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a sentence with inversion.
exercises.answer: Little did he know that someone was watching him
exercises.example_sentence: Little did he know that someone was watching him from the shadows.

exercises.question: Match the inversion triggers with their meanings.
exercises.example_sentence: Rarely do we see such talent in someone so young.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'No sooner had we sat down than the phone rang.'
exercises.answer: No sooner had we sat down than the phone rang.
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had we sat down than the phone rang.

exercises.question: The suspect claimed ___ at the time of the robbery.
exercises.answer: to have been sleeping
exercises.hint: Perfect continuous infinitive (past action in progress).
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect claimed to have been sleeping at the time of the robbery.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses 'not only' inversion correctly?
options: Not only did he arrive late, but he also forgot his notes.
Not only he arrived late, but he also forgot his notes.
Not only he did arrive late, but he also forgot his notes.
exercises.answer: Not only did he arrive late, but he also forgot his notes.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only did he arrive late, but he also forgot his notes for the presentation.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a passive gerund.
exercises.answer: He hates being told what to do by others
exercises.example_sentence: He hates being told what to do by others, especially his peers.

exercises.question: Match the infinitive forms with their examples.
exercises.example_sentence: He was lucky to have been seen by a doctor so quickly.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Only after the meeting did I realize my mistake.'
exercises.answer: Only after the meeting did I realize my mistake.
exercises.example_sentence: Only after the meeting did I realize my mistake.

exercises.question: ___ should you share your password with anyone.
exercises.answer: Under no circumstances
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances should you share your password with anyone.

exercises.question: Which sentence expresses regret about a past action using a gerund?
options: I regret having said that to her.
I regret to say that to her.
I regret to have said that to her.
exercises.answer: I regret having said that to her.
exercises.example_sentence: I deeply regret having said that to her during our argument.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use the continuous infinitive.
exercises.answer: He is likely to be waiting for us outside
exercises.hint: Action happening at the same time as the main verb.
exercises.example_sentence: He is likely to be waiting for us outside the terminal.

exercises.question: Match the verb to its required pattern.
exercises.example_sentence: We managed to finish the project on time.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Seldom does it snow in this part of the country.'
exercises.answer: Seldom does it snow in this part of the country.
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom does it snow in this part of the country.

exercises.question: I would like ___ to the party, but I was busy working.
exercises.answer: to have gone
exercises.example_sentence: I would like to have gone to the party, but I was busy working.

exercises.question: Choose the correct inversion: 'I had hardly arrived...'
options: Hardly had I arrived when the phone rang.
Hardly I had arrived when the phone rang.
Hardly did I arrive when the phone rang.
exercises.answer: Hardly had I arrived when the phone rang.
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had I arrived when the phone rang, interrupting my lunch.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about being recognized.
exercises.answer: He enjoyed being the center of attention
exercises.example_sentence: He enjoyed being the center of attention at the gala.

exercises.question: Scarcely ___ started the presentation when the power went out.
exercises.answer: had she
exercises.example_sentence: Scarcely had she started the presentation when the power went out.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They were reported to have been living in poverty for years.'
exercises.answer: They were reported to have been living in poverty for years.
exercises.example_sentence: They were reported to have been living in poverty for years.

exercises.question: It is essential that every applicant ___ a valid passport for the visa process.
exercises.answer: have
exercises.example_sentence: It is essential that every applicant have a valid passport for the visa process.

exercises.question: Choose the correct substitution: 'Will it rain today?'
exercises.answer: I hope not.
exercises.example_sentence: I hope not, as I have planned a picnic at the park.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a formal fixed expression.
exercises.answer: Be that as it may we must continue
exercises.example_sentence: Be that as it may, we must continue with the project as planned.

exercises.question: Match the subjunctive triggers with the correct base form completion.
exercises.hint: The verb remains in base form regardless of person.
exercises.example_sentence: I suggest that he arrive on time for the meeting tomorrow.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'He hasn't finished his homework, but he really ought to have.'
exercises.answer: He hasn't finished his homework, but he really ought to have.
exercises.hint: Ellipsis at the end of the sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: He hasn't finished his homework, but he really ought to have.

exercises.question: If you need help, please ask; if ___ , I will leave you to work.
exercises.answer: not
exercises.example_sentence: If you need help, please ask; if not, I will leave you to work in peace.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses 'so' as a substitute correctly?
exercises.answer: I believe so.
exercises.example_sentence: 'Is the deadline today?' 'I believe so.'

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a formal requirement.
exercises.answer: They demand that the prisoner be released immediately
exercises.example_sentence: They demand that the prisoner be released immediately.

exercises.question: Match the sentences to their omitted words (Ellipsis).
exercises.example_sentence: Ready yet? We need to leave in five minutes.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I don't think he will come, but if he should, let me know.'
exercises.answer: I don't think he will come, but if he should, let me know.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't think he will come, but if he should, let me know immediately.

exercises.question: I'm not sure if they won, but I ___.
exercises.answer: suppose so
exercises.example_sentence: I'm not sure if they won, but I suppose so given the cheering.

exercises.question: Choose the formal structure: 'Long...'
exercises.answer: Long live the King!
exercises.example_sentence: Long live the King!

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'do so' as substitution.
exercises.answer: She asked him to leave and he did so
exercises.example_sentence: She asked him to leave and he did so without any argument.

exercises.question: Match the substitution phrase with its purpose.
exercises.example_sentence: 'Is the flight cancelled?' 'I'm afraid so.'

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Heaven forbid that we should ever have to do this again.'
exercises.answer: Heaven forbid that we should ever have to do this again.
exercises.example_sentence: Heaven forbid that we should ever have to do this again.

exercises.question: The judge recommended that the defendant ___ a fine.
exercises.answer: pay
exercises.example_sentence: The judge recommended that the defendant pay a fine instead of going to prison.

exercises.question: Choose the correct negative substitution: 'I think it's closed.'
exercises.answer: I don't think so.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't think so, because the lights are still on.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence with auxiliary ellipsis.
exercises.answer: I will help if I can
exercises.example_sentence: I will help if I can, but I am very busy today.

exercises.question: Come what ___ , I will always stand by you.
exercises.answer: may
exercises.example_sentence: Come what may, I will always stand by you through thick and thin.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Do you need a lift?' 'If you wouldn't mind.'
exercises.answer: Do you need a lift? If you wouldn't mind.
exercises.example_sentence: Do you need a lift home? If you wouldn't mind, that would be great.

exercises.question: The lights are off and their car is gone. They ___ out.
exercises.answer: must have gone
exercises.hint: Strong deduction about a past action.
exercises.example_sentence: The lights are off and their car is gone; they must have gone out for dinner.

exercises.question: Choose the correct marker for adding a surprising point: '___, the project was finished under budget.'
exercises.answer: Against all odds
exercises.example_sentence: Against all odds, the project was finished under budget and ahead of schedule.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a past possibility that didn't happen.
exercises.answer: He could have won the race if he hadn't fallen
exercises.example_sentence: He could have won the race if he hadn't fallen near the finish line.

exercises.question: Match the discourse markers with their functions.
exercises.example_sentence: The cost of living is rising; nevertheless, people continue to spend on luxuries.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'She can't have forgotten the meeting; I reminded her this morning.'
exercises.answer: She can't have forgotten the meeting; I reminded her this morning.
exercises.example_sentence: She can't have forgotten the meeting; I reminded her twice this morning.

exercises.question: He's been working for 12 hours straight. He ___ be exhausted.
exercises.answer: must
exercises.example_sentence: He's been working for 12 hours straight; he must be exhausted by now.

exercises.question: Which modal expresses 'it was a bad idea to do that'?
exercises.answer: You shouldn't have told him.
exercises.example_sentence: You shouldn't have told him the secret; now everyone knows.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to introduce a new topic.
exercises.answer: As far as finance is concerned everything stable
exercises.example_sentence: As far as finance is concerned, everything is currently stable.

exercises.question: Match the modal deduction with the level of certainty.
exercises.example_sentence: It can't have been John you saw; he's in Italy this week.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'In a nutshell, we need to increase our sales by ten percent.'
exercises.answer: In a nutshell, we need to increase our sales by ten percent.
exercises.example_sentence: In a nutshell, we need to increase our sales by ten percent to meet our targets.

exercises.question: ___ of the bad weather, the festival was a huge success.
exercises.answer: Regardless
exercises.example_sentence: Regardless of the bad weather, the festival was a huge success.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase: 'He didn't answer his phone.'
exercises.answer: He might have been sleeping.
exercises.example_sentence: He didn't answer his phone; he might have been sleeping.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'by and large'.
exercises.answer: By and large the project has been successful
exercises.example_sentence: By and large, the project has been successful despite initial delays.

exercises.question: Match the sequence markers to their logical order.
exercises.example_sentence: First and foremost, we must ensure safety in the workplace.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I may have made a mistake, but I am willing to fix it.'
exercises.answer: I may have made a mistake, but I am willing to fix it.
exercises.example_sentence: I may have made a mistake, but I am willing to fix it immediately.

exercises.question: You ___ seen Mark at the gym; he's been abroad for months.
exercises.answer: can't have
exercises.hint: Strong negative deduction about the past.
exercises.example_sentence: You can't have seen Mark at the gym; he's been abroad for months.

exercises.question: Which marker is used to correct yourself? 'It will take two hours, ___ three.'
exercises.answer: or rather
exercises.example_sentence: It will take two hours, or rather three, to finish this task.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about unfulfilled obligation.
exercises.answer: You ought to have told me the truth
exercises.example_sentence: You ought to have told me the truth from the beginning.

exercises.question: The software is expensive; ___, it is essential for our work.
exercises.answer: nonetheless
exercises.example_sentence: The software is expensive; nonetheless, it is essential for our daily work.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They might have been delayed by the heavy traffic on the M1.'
exercises.answer: They might have been delayed by the heavy traffic on the M1.
exercises.example_sentence: They might have been delayed by the heavy traffic on the M1.

exercises.question: The suspect is believed ___ the country several days ago.
exercises.answer: to have left
exercises.hint: Personal passive referring to the past.
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect is believed to have left the country several days ago.

exercises.question: Which sentence expresses a regret about a current situation?
options: I wish I lived in a warmer climate.
I wish I had lived in a warmer climate.
I wish I would live in a warmer climate.
exercises.answer: I wish I lived in a warmer climate.
exercises.hint: Wish + past simple for present regret.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I lived in a warmer climate, especially during the winter months.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form an impersonal passive structure.
exercises.answer: It is thought that inflation will continue to rise
exercises.example_sentence: It is thought that inflation will continue to rise throughout the next quarter.

exercises.question: Match the 'wish' structures with their specific meanings.
exercises.hint: Focus on the time and emotion.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish you would stop whistling; it's very distracting.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'He is reported to have been working on a secret project.'
exercises.answer: He is reported to have been working on a secret project.
exercises.example_sentence: He is reported to have been working on a secret project for over a year.

exercises.question: If only I ___ that job offer when I had the chance!
exercises.answer: had accepted
exercises.example_sentence: If only I had accepted that job offer when I had the chance!

exercises.question: Choose the correct reporting structure: 'They say he is a genius.'
options: He is said to be a genius.
He says to be a genius.
It says that he is a genius.
exercises.answer: He is said to be a genius.
exercises.hint: Personal passive (Subject + be + V3 + to infinitive).
exercises.example_sentence: He is said to be a genius in the field of quantum physics.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express frustration with a habit.
exercises.answer: I wish you wouldn't keep interrupting me
exercises.example_sentence: I wish you wouldn't keep interrupting me while I'm on the phone.

exercises.question: Match the passive verbs with their typical reporting contexts.
exercises.example_sentence: The cost of the damage is estimated to be over a million dollars.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'If only we had more time to finish the presentation.'
exercises.answer: If only we had more time to finish the presentation.
exercises.hint: Expressing a current lack of something.
exercises.example_sentence: If only we had more time to finish the presentation, it would be perfect.

exercises.question: The ruins are understood ___ back to the 12th century.
exercises.answer: to date
exercises.example_sentence: The ruins are understood to date back to the 12th century.

exercises.question: Which sentence indicates that something was expected but didn't happen?
options: The meeting was to have started at ten.
The meeting was starting at ten.
The meeting had started at ten.
exercises.answer: The meeting was to have started at ten.
exercises.example_sentence: The meeting was to have started at ten, but the CEO was delayed.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a past regret.
exercises.answer: I wish I hadn't spent so much money yesterday
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I hadn't spent so much money yesterday at the mall.

exercises.question: Match the passive structure to the timeframe it describes.

pairs.left: He is said to be living...
He is said to have lived...
He is said to have been living...

answer.left: He is said to be living...
He is said to have lived...
He is said to have been living...

exercises.example_sentence: He is said to have been living in Paris before he moved here.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I wish I could help you, but I'm swamped with work.'
exercises.answer: I wish I could help you, but I'm swamped with work.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I could help you with the move, but I'm swamped with work.

exercises.question: It ___ that the new highway will be completed by next year.
exercises.answer: is expected
exercises.example_sentence: It is expected that the new highway will be completed by next year.

exercises.question: Choose the correct form for an impossible wish: 'I wish I ___ fly.'
exercises.answer: could
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I could fly so I could avoid the morning traffic.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use the 'alleged' passive.
exercises.answer: The company is alleged to have evaded tax
exercises.example_sentence: The company is alleged to have evaded tax for several years.

exercises.question: I wish you ___ stop checking your phone during dinner.
exercises.answer: would
exercises.example_sentence: I wish you would stop checking your phone during dinner; it's quite rude.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The painting is thought to be a genuine Van Gogh.'
exercises.answer: The painting is thought to be a genuine Van Gogh.
exercises.example_sentence: The painting is thought to be a genuine Van Gogh and is worth millions.

exercises.question: I have two sisters, but ___ of them live in this city.
exercises.answer: neither
exercises.example_sentence: I have two sisters, but neither of them live in this city anymore.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'every' to mean 'all in a group'?
options: Every student has their own locker.
Each students have their own locker.
Every students has their own locker.
exercises.answer: Every student has their own locker.
exercises.example_sentence: Every student has their own locker in the hallway.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'either... or'.
exercises.answer: You can either take the bus or walk home
exercises.example_sentence: You can either take the bus or walk home; it's up to you.

exercises.question: Match the quantifiers with their correct usage.

pairs.right: Zero out of three or more.

answer.right: Zero out of three or more.

exercises.hint: Focus on the number of items.
exercises.example_sentence: None of the applicants met the specific requirements.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Neither the manager nor the employees were happy with the new policy.'
exercises.answer: Neither the manager nor the employees were happy with the new policy.
exercises.example_sentence: Neither the manager nor the employees were happy with the new policy.

exercises.question: ___ of the five candidates was suitable for the position.
exercises.answer: None
exercises.hint: Use for a group of more than two.
exercises.example_sentence: None of the five candidates was suitable for the senior position.

exercises.question: Choose the correct article use for a general class: '___ computer has changed the world.'
exercises.answer: The
exercises.hint: 'The' + singular noun can represent a whole invention/species.
exercises.example_sentence: The computer has changed the world more than any other invention.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'each' for individual focus.
exercises.answer: Each participant was given a folder of documents
exercises.hint: Focusing on members one by one.
exercises.example_sentence: Each participant was given a folder of documents at the start.

exercises.question: Match the article scenarios with the correct rule.

pairs.right: Specific (e.g., the life of a bird).

answer.right: Specific (e.g., the life of a bird).

exercises.example_sentence: The government is trying to help the unemployed.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I don't like either of these options, to be honest.'
exercises.answer: I don't like either of these options, to be honest.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't like either of these options, to be honest with you.

exercises.question: ___ day I spend here, I like the city more.
exercises.answer: Each
exercises.hint: Often used for a series of individual days.
exercises.example_sentence: Each day I spend here, I like the city more and more.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence for 'neither' used as a conjunction.
options: Neither he nor I could believe it.
Neither he or I could believe it.
Either he nor I could believe it.
exercises.answer: Neither he nor I could believe it.
exercises.example_sentence: Neither he nor I could believe what had happened.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to discuss a general concept.
exercises.answer: Happiness is more important than money
exercises.hint: Abstract nouns usually have no article.
exercises.example_sentence: Happiness is more important than money for most people.

exercises.question: Match the quantifiers to their verb agreement.
exercises.example_sentence: Every one of us has a responsibility to help.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The rich should do more to help the poor in our society.'
exercises.answer: The rich should do more to help the poor in our society.
exercises.hint: Article + adjective to describe a group.
exercises.example_sentence: The rich should do more to help the poor in our society.

exercises.question: I've read ___ book on this shelf over the last year.
exercises.answer: every
exercises.hint: Used for a large, indefinite number.
exercises.example_sentence: I've read every book on this shelf over the last year.

exercises.question: Identify the error: 'None of the two options is good.'
exercises.answer: Use 'Neither' instead of 'None'.
exercises.hint: When there are only two, 'neither' is the correct choice.
exercises.example_sentence: Neither of the two options is good for our budget.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about technology.
exercises.answer: The Internet has changed how we communicate
exercises.example_sentence: The Internet has fundamentally changed how we communicate.

exercises.question: You can have ___ tea or coffee; we have both.
exercises.answer: either
exercises.example_sentence: You can have either tea or coffee; we have both in the kitchen.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Each of the students has to submit the assignment by Friday.'
exercises.answer: Each of the students has to submit the assignment by Friday.
exercises.example_sentence: Each of the students has to submit the assignment by Friday.

exercises.question: I'll lend you the money ___ you pay me back by next month.
exercises.answer: provided that
exercises.example_sentence: I'll lend you the money provided that you pay me back by next month.

exercises.question: Which participial clause correctly replaces: 'Because he had finished his work, he went home'?
options: Having finished his work, he went home.
Finished his work, he went home.
To have finished his work, he went home.
exercises.answer: Having finished his work, he went home.
exercises.example_sentence: Having finished his work, he went home earlier than usual.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a condition using 'unless'.
exercises.answer: We won't be able to go unless it stops raining
exercises.example_sentence: We won't be able to go for a hike unless it stops raining soon.

exercises.question: Match the conditional linkers with their meanings.

pairs.right: Whether or not the condition is met.

answer.right: Whether or not the condition is met.

exercises.example_sentence: Take an umbrella in case it rains later.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Not wanting to wake the baby, she tiptoed out of the room.'
exercises.answer: Not wanting to wake the baby, she tiptoed out of the room.
exercises.example_sentence: Not wanting to wake the baby, she tiptoed out of the room.

exercises.question: ___ you are careful, you can use my camera.
exercises.answer: As long as
exercises.example_sentence: As long as you are careful, you can use my camera for your project.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence for a 'precaution'.
options: I'll take a coat in case it gets cold.
I'll take a coat if it gets cold.
I'll take a coat unless it gets cold.
exercises.answer: I'll take a coat in case it gets cold.
exercises.hint: You take the coat before it gets cold.
exercises.example_sentence: I'll take a coat in case it gets cold in the evening.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a passive participial clause.
exercises.answer: Built in the 19th century the house needs repairs
exercises.example_sentence: Built in the 19th century, the house now needs extensive repairs.

exercises.question: Match the participle types to their function.
exercises.example_sentence: Being watched by the crowd, the athlete felt nervous.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Provided that everyone agrees, we will move the deadline to next Monday.'
exercises.answer: Provided that everyone agrees, we will move the deadline to next Monday.
exercises.example_sentence: Provided that everyone agrees, we will move the deadline to next Monday.

exercises.question: ___ by the news, she couldn't speak for a moment.
exercises.answer: Shocked
exercises.example_sentence: Shocked by the news, she couldn't speak for a moment.

exercises.question: Which sentence is more formal? 'Because I didn't know the way...'
options: Not knowing the way, I got lost.
I didn't know the way so I got lost.
I got lost because I didn't know the way.
exercises.answer: Not knowing the way, I got lost.
exercises.hint: Participial clauses are common in formal writing.
exercises.example_sentence: Not knowing the way, I got lost in the city center.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'otherwise'.
exercises.answer: Leave now otherwise you will miss the train
exercises.example_sentence: Leave now; otherwise, you will miss the last train home.

exercises.question: Match the linker to the correct grammatical structure.

pairs.right: Used in questions (Supposing he says no?).
Often triggers inversion (Only if... will I).

answer.right: Used in questions (Supposing he says no?).
Often triggers inversion (Only if... will I).

exercises.example_sentence: But for your help, I wouldn't have finished the project.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Having been warned about the traffic, we left early.'
exercises.answer: Having been warned about the traffic, we left early.
exercises.example_sentence: Having been warned about the traffic, we left early for the airport.

exercises.question: ___ down the street, I ran into an old friend.
exercises.answer: Walking
exercises.hint: Action happening at the same time as the main verb.
exercises.example_sentence: Walking down the street, I ran into an old friend from high school.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'as long as' for a promise?
options: I'll help you as long as you promise to try your best.
I'll help you in case you promise to try your best.
I'll help you unless you promise to try your best.
exercises.answer: I'll help you as long as you promise to try your best.
exercises.example_sentence: I'll help you as long as you promise to try your best.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to form a 'perfect participle' clause.
exercises.answer: Having found the key he opened the door
exercises.example_sentence: Having found the key, he opened the door and went inside.

exercises.question: You should bring your passport ___ they ask for ID at the gate.
exercises.answer: in case
exercises.example_sentence: You should bring your passport in case they ask for ID at the gate.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Supposing you won the lottery, what would you do first?'
exercises.answer: Supposing you won the lottery, what would you do first?
exercises.example_sentence: Supposing you won the lottery, what would you do first with the money?

exercises.question: The ___ actor signed autographs for hours after the show.
exercises.answer: well-known
exercises.example_sentence: The well-known actor signed autographs for hours after the show.

exercises.question: Choose the correct order of adverbs: 'He...'
options: He spoke quite well in the interview yesterday.
He spoke yesterday quite well in the interview.
He spoke in the interview yesterday quite well.
exercises.answer: He spoke quite well in the interview yesterday.
exercises.example_sentence: He spoke quite well in the interview yesterday afternoon.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to describe a duration using a compound adjective.
exercises.answer: It was a three-hour meeting that exhausted everyone
exercises.hint: Compound adjectives of measurement are singular (not 'three-hours').
exercises.example_sentence: It was a three-hour meeting that exhausted everyone in the office.

exercises.question: Match the gradable adjectives with their extreme (ungradable) counterparts.
exercises.hint: Extreme adjectives often use 'absolutely' instead of 'very'.
exercises.example_sentence: The movie wasn't just funny; it was hilarious!

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I was absolutely terrified when the lights went out.'
exercises.answer: I was absolutely terrified when the lights went out.
exercises.example_sentence: I was absolutely terrified when the lights suddenly went out.

exercises.question: We went on a ___ hike through the mountains.
exercises.answer: ten-mile
exercises.hint: Hyphenated numbers acting as adjectives lose the 's'.
exercises.example_sentence: We went on a ten-mile hike through the mountains yesterday.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses 'hardly' correctly?
options: I could hardly breathe in the crowded room.
I worked hardly on my final project.
He hardly works so he is very successful.
exercises.answer: I could hardly breathe in the crowded room.
exercises.example_sentence: I could hardly breathe in the crowded room because it was so hot.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use an intensifying adverb.
exercises.answer: The morning was bitterly cold and windy
exercises.hint: Bitterly + cold is a common collocation.
exercises.example_sentence: The morning was bitterly cold and windy, so we stayed inside.

exercises.question: Match the adverbs with the verbs they typically modify.
exercises.example_sentence: I distinctly remember locking the door before I left.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The long-awaited news finally arrived this morning.'
exercises.answer: The long-awaited news finally arrived this morning.
exercises.example_sentence: The long-awaited news finally arrived this morning.

exercises.question: It's ___ impossible to finish all this work by 5 PM.
exercises.answer: virtually
exercises.example_sentence: It's virtually impossible to finish all this work by 5 PM.

exercises.question: Choose the correct compound adjective: 'a...'
exercises.answer: a never-ending story
exercises.example_sentence: Cleaning the house with kids around is a never-ending story.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to place the adverb 'seldom' correctly.
exercises.answer: We seldom go out to dinner during the week
exercises.hint: Adverbs of frequency go before the main verb.
exercises.example_sentence: We seldom go out to dinner during the week because we are tired.

exercises.question: Match the modifiers to their adjective types.
exercises.hint: Matching intensity with the right adjective category.
exercises.example_sentence: His explanation was perfectly clear to everyone.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'She is a highly-qualified professional with years of experience.'
exercises.answer: She is a highly-qualified professional with years of experience.
exercises.example_sentence: She is a highly-qualified professional with years of experience.

exercises.question: The room was ___ empty when I arrived.
exercises.answer: completely
exercises.example_sentence: The room was completely empty when I arrived for the meeting.

exercises.question: Choose the correctly hyphenated age adjective.
exercises.answer: A five-year-old child.
exercises.hint: Compound adjectives describing age need hyphens.
exercises.example_sentence: A five-year-old child can usually count to twenty.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence with 'lately'.
exercises.answer: I haven't seen any good movies lately
exercises.example_sentence: I haven't seen any good movies lately, have you?

exercises.question: He was ___ sorry for the misunderstanding.
exercises.answer: genuinely
exercises.example_sentence: He was genuinely sorry for the misunderstanding that occurred.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'It was a fast-paced thriller that kept me on the edge of my seat.'
exercises.answer: It was a fast-paced thriller that kept me on the edge of my seat.
exercises.example_sentence: It was a fast-paced thriller that kept me on the edge of my seat.
